lg.l: Volcanic Isle! Volcanic isle. Whakaari/White Island is an active submarine volcano in the Bay of Plenty, in the north of the North Island. thy fame world-wide has spread;
Mysterious crater of deep-centred fire,
With fleecy steam-clouds billowing overhead
Tossed upward ever by thy pent up ire.
Thy riven portal, Riven portal. The cliffs surrounding Whakaari/White Island are broken in only one place, Crater Bay, where ships are able to land. through its open door,
Admits the trav’ller to a rock-strewn beach.

We land, We land. The same issue of the Bay of Plenty Times where the poem was published includes an article describing a visit to Whakaari/White Island by a tourist party, which mirrors many of the descriptions in the poem. The poet’s pseudonym, “Staffa,” is taken from the name of the tourists’ steamship. in haste, thy beauties to explore,
Prepared to learn whate’er thou hast to teach.
Upon thy many-tinted hues we gaze
With growing wonder; but words fail to tell
Our admiration, as the sun’s bright rays
Illume each cliff and jutting pinnacle.
Rich brown thy walls, with sulphur veined,
And here and there a rift, which seems to speak
Of some convulsion that had rent and strained
And well nigh from their centre made them break.
But when we stand upon the crater’s brink
And peer into that awful dark green cave,
From its unfathomable depth we shrink;
For who falls in no human power could save.
Yet still we gaze spellbound, as forth in clouds
All noiselessly rolls up the rushing steam,
Which ever and anon the rock enshrouds
Like moving phantom of some baseless dream.
At length we tear ourselves away, to view
The varied wonders every turn displays
Of boiling lake, and pool of strangest hue,
Which, hissing weirdly, fill us with amaze.
For here has nature mixed, with lavish hand,

Such healing blessings Healing blessings. A reference to the medicinal properties of sulphur, which had been mined on the island since the late 1870s, and further expanded in late 1884 by the newly-formed New Zealand Manure and Chemical Company. for the hours of pain,
That he whose cramped limbs can no longer stand,
Bathing—restores their wonted powers again.
Farewell, lone Isle! we shudder at the thought
Of all the fiery power pent up in thee,
Lest it some day Some day. Mining ceased on Whakaari/White Island after ten miners were killed in 1914 after part of the volcano’s crater rim collapsed. should shatter thee to naught,
Or hurl thee headlong in th’ encircling sea.
